tweets.text: You'd think nothing would be more obvious than to avoid policies that will kill large numbers of children. You'd think. https://t.co/6NkSRyJAk5
Replying to a cold email you sent me in order to get it back to the top of my inbox is not the way to my heart.

It seems to me that the probability of a lab leak is high enough that we should just treat it as the default explanation unless the Chinese government can prove otherwise. Then instead of winning by not being transparent, they lose. https://t.co/GR17m9kZmW

80% of the "vibe shift" was the end of wokeness. The reason it happened so fast and so thoroughly was that wokeness consisted of a small number of zealots terrifying most moderates into submission. So it ended like a bubble bursting, and there is no going back. https://t.co/qhnUq3SfzR
The Victorians showed us how much is too much.
Due process. Rule of law. The most important principles sound the most boring.

If you're wondering what an "ASP" is, that was a short-lived name for what eventually came to be called a SaaS company. There was no name for it when we started the first one, just as there was no name for an accelerator when we started YC.

I'd forgotten how informal the first bios I wrote for us were. The reason Jessica was called the Fourth Man (a reference to the Cambridge spy ring) was that she hadn't quit her previous job yet. https://t.co/R57OZCDURu

A report from the front lines of the trade war. As in other wars, the generals don't understand the consequences of their decisions, but the individual soldiers know them all too well. https://t.co/wlbnRZHgoo

This is a good example of a subtle but important aspect of Y Combinator. There are certain tunnels in society through which talented outsiders can become insiders much more rapidly than everywhere else, and YC is one of them. https://t.co/nA0u86JT50
Watch with the sound on. https://t.co/09mmUpsbbQ

"I want them to know what a loser I was. No other graduation speaker is going to tell them that."

— Jessica working on the commencement speech she's giving at Bucknell this year
So it should be. That's the point of ethics: to stop you from doing something you'd like to do, but that would be wrong. https://t.co/PnIQp2lXEY
To my delight someone asked me this morning how long we'd been doing Y Combinator, and I was able to answer "Exactly 20 years."

Y Combinator's 20th birthday is tomorrow. Here's what was happening on March 11, 2005: https://t.co/uEctjPUohb

(Yeah, I know this tweet will get hidden because it has a link in it, and that I'm supposed to put the link in a reply. But that's so stupid that I refuse to do it.)

Imagine how great it would be to have a president who was neither decrepit nor a lout. It's been so long (8 years) that I can barely remember what it's like. And yet we used to be able to take this for granted. I never thought I'd long for Gerald Ford, but I do.

So what I tell my kids about AI is to keep an eye on it. Maybe there will be an opportunity to do something amazing with it. Or maybe it will consume the field they'd been planning to enter. But never turn your back on the ocean.

Technological revolutions always have unexpected consequences, but the AI Revolution is going to be extreme in this respect. No one knows what's going to happen. I've never had a conversation with an expert who said "Ok, here's how it's all going to play out."

People often ask what I tell my kids about AI. I tell them I'm reluctant to give them any too specific advice, because one of the most distinctive things about this wave of technology is the unpredictability of the outcome.
Rule of thumb: When people deny even the possibility of social contagion, there is a lot of social contagion happening. https://t.co/8IXDL0ndwh

Pétain and the Vichy government have very few open fans, but if it was happening now, they'd have lots of fans on Twitter. Or at least there would be lots of accounts posting in support of them, many of which would be fake.

When I searched for that quote, I found I'd tweeted a link to the same article, with the same quote drawn from it, five years ago.

https://t.co/fj4Ht5FfqS
"In families, love flows downhill." https://t.co/cfIAJjkowr

Good sci-fi writers usually insure themselves against technological progress by not being too specific about how things work. But it's hard not to be specific about who's doing things. That's what a plot is.

The rate of progress in AI must be making it hard to write science fiction right now. To appeal to human readers you want to make humans (or living creatures at least) solve problems, but if you do the shelf life of your story could be short.

Fortunately for most of us it's a very natural kind of effort to make. Jessica and I hate the sort of bureaucratic formality you find at big companies, and so do most YC partners. Garry in particular does. So I'm pretty confident about the immediate future.

It will be YC's 20th birthday in 4 days. I'm pleased by how young YC still feels as an organization. It would be dangerous for YC to become too established. Since YC is training startups, it has to remain startupish itself. But it requires a constant effort to stay that way.

A high school student asked if he should join a startup or go to university. I said that if he was ambitious he could learn a lot more at a university. The work you do in a startup is severely constrained. If it isn't, the startup is inefficient.
You know the founders are still running things when a company can talk openly about its "most hated feature." Hired managers would never dare to be so candid. https://t.co/Uyd6Yep3ZU
For the 10% of the US electorate who were nodding their heads in agreement as they read that: I'm joking.
Whatever the practical difficulties involved in invading Canada, the moral position at least is clear. Canadians all speak English, which makes them ethnically American, so it's ok to invade.
I seem to be willing to spend unlimited amounts of time trying to start today's fire from the microscopic glowing embers of yesterday's rather than just using a match.

I just came across a school application we filled out for our older son when he was 4 (in Palo Alto you have to apply to competitive schools) and one of the questions was to describe a day in his life. I'm so pleased now that I had to do this. https://t.co/XamwRDxtxj
Which of America's bold new cohort of Republican leaders is bold enough to answer this? https://t.co/ZORjuOS8K2
Judging from the replies, something is happening. https://t.co/VwxrO5HNzS
People sometimes speculate about whether YC would have funded Apple. We would have if Steve Jobs wanted us to, because Steve Jobs got what he wanted.
Heuristic for US foreign policy: You should not be competing with South Park's writers. https://t.co/Pq67rG0T39

This is the larval form of a $3 trillion company. It's very different looking, but not unrecognizable. In fact Y Combinator specializes in recognizing and helping it. (image via @JonErlichman) https://t.co/iprQGjAKQ5

It's a false analogy to think that it's more impressive to start a startup at 18 than at 22. It's more impressive to solve a given problem at 18 than 22. But the startup in these two cases is not constant. The one you start at 22 will be better.
Potential metric for the richness of fiction: ratio of minifigs to pages, if Lego made sets based on it.
This is about 4% of a Bruegel and it's better than almost every other painting. That's how good he was. https://t.co/ruJubj04Ce

When you consider that you could run a fleet of 100,000 Twitter accounts with blue checks for less than $10 million a year, a foreign power that wanted to influence US politics would be pretty slack if they didn't try to create one.

It's such an affectation to use diacritics in translations from Arabic. Does the translator really think I won't be able to pronounce wazir unless he writes it as wazīr, or that someone who doesn't know how to pronounce it will be able to once supplied with this valuable clue?
John Berkey's space ships are calligraphic flourishes. https://t.co/0dmSwQaPoq

12 yo was puzzled why a grocery store chain would run ads talking about their use of AI. I explained that these ads aren't aimed at customers, but investors. Their goal is to make them think of the grocery chain's stock as an AI stock.

It's easy to make fun of founders who say this kind of thing, but Steve really meant it. He not only meant it, but did it.

The people who say that professors deserve to have their universities blown up are forgetting two other groups who will be hurt by the attack on them: our kids, who will be attending them as students, and all of us, who benefit from the research done at them.

I wonder if in retrospect this will have been the biggest news of February 2025, rather than any of the political controversies most people are exercised about. History often turns out like that. https://t.co/kbkFPGpHub

The quiet, apolitical majority of professors must be so bummed. First wokeness infected the institutions where they worked and they lost the ability to speak freely about many subjects, and now they're collateral damage in air strikes by the Republicans.
The suggestion that one should put links in replies is such an obviously broken workaround. Who, starting from scratch, would design Twitter to work like that?

There are a lot of people attributing crazy beliefs to Elon lately, but to me the clearest sign that he's not entirely rational is the continued deprioritization of tweets with links in them. Everyone can see that this makes Twitter worse.

Interesting data point about the date of Trump's mental model of the world. Television repairmen disappeared in the 1990s. https://t.co/ChzdntWCuF
Twitter seems a bit impoverished now that so many leftish users have fled. They may have been wronger on average about politics, but they were more interesting on average about other topics.
The last administration appointed unqualified people to top government jobs because of DEI. The current one is doing it out of... sheer cluelessness? https://t.co/yExXfdfwgt

Cruft breeds cruft.

(If you're not familiar with the word "cruft," it means an accumulation of unnecessary stuff.)

This is related to a problem that a lot of "literary" mid-20th century novels suffer from: the writer wants to show that he's cleverer than any of his characters. One reason Sherlock Holmes stories are so good is that Doyle doesn't do this.

The solution is to show how clever you are in the opposite way: by thinking of cool things the startup could do instead of ways it could fail. Though of course to use this strategy you have be able to think of them.
One of the most dangerous temptations investors face is the temptation to find problems with startups in order to show how clever they are. This can make them reject companies that end up doing well.
I bet mathematicians and scientists are more partial to the Great Man theory of history than the general population. However things work in the rest of the world, it's certainly true in theirs.
I still remember the shipping address of Viaweb's most persistent would-be fraudster: Sarmizegetusa St, Iasi, Romania.
The really striking thing about this case is that this startup is several years old, and yet they have growth that would be impressive during YC, in a company starting from nothing.

DMs with a founder. This kind of growth is about as good as it gets.

Founder: We’re making so much money btw.  

Me: I don't care how much; I care about the growth rate; what's that?  

Founder: 46.8% MoM  

Me: Whoah. For how long?  

Founder: Since September

It will be particularly difficult for Bond, because as created by Ian Fleming he's intrinsically naughty: a white dude (already bad) who goes through a series of younger lovers. What large corporation will be able to resist sanitizing (or as they'll call it, "updating") him?

It would be nice if Bond could avoid the fate that Star Wars suffered after it was handed over to the suits at Disney, but what are the odds? The creator of a franchise can resist soulless execs, but one that's acquired starts out already in their hands. https://t.co/XSij1wxDxZ

Whereas clearly explaining the risks that a startup faces actually *helps* explain the idea, and what's new about it. In fact a description of the risks might be, per word, the most valuable explanatory material in a startup's pitch.

A related mistake founders make is to underestimate how easy it is to confuse investors with an unclear pitch. The founders are familiar with their idea, but investors are seeing it for the first time. So even a small loss of clarity can lose them.

It is therefore a big mistake for early stage startups to conceal the risks they face by being vague or evasive. You're hiding something that won't bother experts using something that will. Just admit the risks upfront, and explain why the EV is high nonetheless.

The worst thing a pitch to professional investors can be is confusing. Professional investors are willing to give early stage startups the benefit of the doubt. They're ok with risk. But they can't invest in a startup whose pitch they can't even follow.

Since Robert Reich is tweeting again, here is how people actually get rich in America (and why they get so much richer now than they used to):

https://t.co/ggPKu1gN8u
The phrase "next team" is an interesting slip. They expect their behavior to get them voted out of office. https://t.co/sYS1CIzzuV
This is brilliant. https://t.co/jsCIOlPZz8
Bertrand Russell on the fundamental difference between liberal and illiberal thinking (via @SteveStuWill): https://t.co/qeJfl5nkHq

The founders I met today will probably do alright. They're smart and have a good idea. But the thing they'll do alright at (starting a company) is just a subset of the true problem (having a good life).

I don't approve of that at all. If students decide on their own to drop out of college to start startups, it's fine to help them. But it seems over the line to actively encourage them to drop out, especially at 18.

The AI revolution is causing a lot more founders to drop out of college to start startups. Today I did office hours with a pair of 18 year olds who dropped out to start a startup after some investors offered them $750k based on a paper they'd published.

An interesting, unexpected effect of the AI revolution: big companies seem to be more willing to buy from young founders. I'm not sure why. It could because they expect younger founders to understand AI better (as in fact they do). Or maybe they just need the software more.

How strange it would be if a regulation driven largely by European anger about American dominance in the previous generation of technology ended up ensuring that Europe remained behind in the latest generation. Or maybe not so strange. Bitterness is never a strategy for winning.
After talking to an AI startup from Europe in the current YC batch, it's clear that the GDPR conflicts with AI in an unforeseen way that will significantly harm European AI companies.

I wish anything else in my life was running as smoothly as YC is under Garry. We just had a board meeting and it seemed like every item on the agenda was about how to make something that's working well work even better.

It is surprising, but my guess is that it's not because they like Putin per se, but because they hate the high-handed smugness of the left establishment so much. I.e. this is a reaction in the purest sense. https://t.co/LQsrdRYPbf
I would like this to be true. Maybe it is. https://t.co/I8BXXLlcEs

Paradoxically, the harder your startup's product is to build, the less of your time you'll get to spend building it. If you start a consumer web app you'll get to spend a lot of time programming. But if you start a fusion company you'll be mostly fundraising.

My heart sinks when a startup sends me a Carta link. Carta clearly has a vision of the world where everything to do with the mechanics of startup funding happens on Carta. But just using email is so much quicker and more flexible.
I remember feeling this for the first time in 1983... https://t.co/NIur01d8tx

Every time we come back to SV, my 16 yo son gets a massive dose of cognitive dissonance when he notices that apparently smart and reasonable people seem eager to obtain something he's convinced is utterly worthless.

After we hired Harj Taggar as YC's first employee, I asked him what surprised him most about how YC worked behind the scenes. One of the things he mentioned was how much we laughed. It was true. I think there ought to be a lot of laughing at a well-run incubator.

A startup in the current YC batch was trying to choose between two strategies, and I advised them to choose the funnier one. This is not as frivolous as it sounds. The best startup ideas often seem a bit preposterous.
Alexandr Wang is so interesting to talk to. The first time I met him we talked for an hour and we had to arrange a second meeting because we weren't finished. https://t.co/aVHnFLdP74
12 yo asked when poverty first became a problem. I told him it was the default — that most animal species are hungry.
Though the real answer, which Jessica finally guessed, was people who don't know how to handle books mangling my books.

We played a game about how well you know your family. Jessica and the boys had to say what I dreaded. Some of their guesses: having to wear a suit, pretentious waiters, having to sit through powerpoints. Basically anything with gratuitous formality.

Phrases like "I don't want to be that guy" and "I hate to be the bearer of bad news" are interesting in that the more you say them, the less likely they are to be true. 

Once you've said "I don't want to be that guy" 100 times or so, you are that guy.
You have to give credit where credit is due: the current administration seems more aware of the progress being made toward a supersonic airliner. https://t.co/K2wc0AxJjp

This is what success looks like in tech: exponential growth that's very steep, and consistent for years. Usually only cumulative numbers look this good. But these aren't cumulative, as you can see from the occasional downward spikes. https://t.co/lbnOYoTX4s
There's no reason we can't fix this regulation right now. We don't have to wait for the planes. https://t.co/W3U5YcXHgZ

1892684954842091625.text:
BREAKING: Speaker Mike Johnson just announced the House plans to codify much of Trump's 300 executive orders into law.

"The president has over 300 executive actions already, and we're going to codify so much of what he's doing so that the next team can't unwind it."

H/t… https://t.co/gpeznTovvG https://t.co/jLfCEWVoAk

1892671633875206277.text:
Don’t work at Anduril. 
It’s just built different. https://t.co/91FtxXFzEh

1892726776851243473.text: I don't approve of that at all. If students decide on their own to drop out of college to start startups, it's fine to help them. But it seems over the line to actively encourage them to drop out, especially at 18.

1892726141355798945.text: The AI revolution is causing a lot more founders to drop out of college to start startups. Today I did office hours with a pair of 18 year olds who dropped out to start a startup after some investors offered them $750k based on a paper they'd published.

1892719419769713043.text: After talking to an AI startup from Europe in the current YC batch, it's clear that the GDPR conflicts with AI in an unforeseen way that will significantly harm European AI companies.

1891685627340447853.text: Admiration by so many Republicans for Putin--a brutal dictator with no respect for human life, individual liberties, or private property, who hates America -- is one of the most shocking developments of my life. Never saw that coming.

1891962633059958982.text: People who are good at coming up with ideas will enjoy great leverage in the age of AI

1891560132259041783.text: i’ve trained a model that can operate on abstract syntax trees directly instead of the textual representation of code, and the results are incredible. more soon

1891268875007762832.text: A startup in the current YC batch was trying to choose between two strategies, and I advised them to choose the funnier one. This is not as frivolous as it sounds. The best startup ideas often seem a bit preposterous.

1889737906786382128.text:
I loved our wide-ranging conversation with Alexandr Wang of @scale_AI in this week's Social Radars. Scale has been supplying training data to a lot of the big AI models since 2016, so he has a deep understanding of where AI is and where it's going.

https://t.co/XRlthTQDuy https://t.co/VeXg85SpXM

1891104526687436942.text: We played a game about how well you know your family. Jessica and the boys had to say what I dreaded. Some of their guesses: having to wear a suit, pretentious waiters, having to sit through powerpoints. Basically anything with gratuitous formality.

1889000973013852569.text: My least favorite regulation is 14CFR 91.817—which prohibits supersonic flight regardless of noise profile. But it's easy to fix to allow boomless supersonic flight.

tweets.text: i love riding caltrain! it's the best https://t.co/MHmT4DEw6c

this is a tremendous accomplishment from the team.

i am obviously biased but i think it's one of the most well-designed and useful APIs ever, and that people will really love it. https://t.co/0J94UHD9IN

YC changed the startup ecosystem--maybe the whole tech industry--more than anything else over the past two decades. and the impact on many people's lives (including mine) has been astonishing.

 what a happy photo. https://t.co/SVqKB8lT1E
! https://t.co/qCboulpyzX

we trained a new model that is good at creative writing (not sure yet how/when it will get released). this is the first time i have been really struck by something written by AI; it got the vibe of metafiction so right.

PROMPT:

Please write a metafictional literary short story… https://t.co/t8cjY2o5NN
i love this model

GPT-4.5 rollout to plus users has started

will complete within the next few days
(i realize i am getting neurochemically hacked here but idc, it's the best)

very proud of the openai team for what is perhaps the most impressive scientific/technical breakthrough of recent decades

thought that was the thing i'd always be most proud of in life

turns out i am now more proud of a preemie baby for learning how to eat on his own!

so we think it's better to let people have real, long conversations with it, but that means we have to stagger people in rather than have everyone hit it hard a the same time.

hope that makes sense and look forward to seeing your feedback!

we are likely going to roll out GPT-4.5 to the plus tier over a few days.

there is no perfect way to do this; we wanted to do it for everyone tomorrow, but it would have meant we had to launch with a very low rate limit.

we think people are gonna use this a lot and love it.

an idea for paid plans: your $20 plus subscription converts to credits you can use across features like deep research, o1, gpt-4.5, sora, etc.

no fixed limits per feature and you choose what you want; if you run out of credits you can buy more.

what do you think? good/bad?
excited for this--advancing research and education with AI https://t.co/hSwiJMvWfc
!!! https://t.co/aPZxifRWSd
!! https://t.co/shWj7H6STl
once in awhile the high taste testers are right

GPT-4.5 is the first time people have been emailing with such passion asking us to promise to never stop offering a specific model or even replace it with an update

great work @kaicathyc @rapha_gl @mia_glaese

it's very hard to get the math and ML right on a run as big as GPT-4.5, and requires difficult work at the intersection of ML and systems.

@ColinWei11 , Yujia Jin, and @MikhailPavlov5 did excellent work to make this happen!
lol if facebook tries to come at us and we just uno reverse them it would be so funny 🤣
ok fine maybe we'll do a social app https://t.co/663VkHN4qB

GPT-4.5 is ready!

good news: it is the first model that feels like talking to a thoughtful person to me. i have had several moments where i've sat back in my chair and been astonished at getting actually good advice from an AI.

bad news: it is a giant, expensive model. we… https://t.co/2fPSsVKSxE

deep research out for chatgpt plus users!

one of my favorite things we have ever shipped.

welcome to the world, little guy!

he came early and is going to be in the nicu for awhile. he is doing well and it’s really nice to be in a little bubble taking care of him.

i have never felt such love. https://t.co/wFF2FkKiMU
for our next open source project, would it be more useful to do an o3-mini level model that is pretty small but still needs to run on GPUs, or the best phone-sized model we can do?
trying GPT-4.5 has been much more of a "feel the AGI" moment among high-taste testers than i expected!
i particularly love when the anti-AI crowd makes up shit about our water usage while eating a hamburger https://t.co/nXmJR1vuca

we put out an update to chatgpt (4o).

it is pretty good.

it is soon going to get much better, team is cooking.
really proud of this work: https://t.co/v0HdUEhCK3

OPENAI ROADMAP UPDATE FOR GPT-4.5 and GPT-5:

We want to do a better job of sharing our intended roadmap, and a much better job simplifying our product offerings.

We want AI to “just work” for you; we realize how complicated our model and product offerings have gotten.

We hate… https://t.co/A6NwRZ97Z9

longer-term we still have to find some way to let people to pay for compute they want to use more dynamically.

we have been really struck by the demand from some users to hit deep research dozens of times per day.

i think we are going to initially offer 10 uses per month for chatgpt plus and 2 per month in the free tier, with the intent to scale these up over time.

it probably is worth $1000 a month to some users but i'm excited to see what everyone does with it! https://t.co/YBICvzodPF
no thank you but we will buy twitter for $9.74 billion if you want
an ode to the history of technology, and human potential: https://t.co/VMXSqKVyv8
man, still a long way to go to run down google 🥺 https://t.co/MdD3as1lIU

Three Observations:

https://t.co/Ctvga5vfMy

chains of thought for o3-mini!

(we try to organize the raw CoT to make it more readable, and optionally to translate languages, but we try to keep it quite faithful to the raw one)

great work from @mia_glaese, @joannejang, @akshaynathan_ , and their teams! https://t.co/A8JZIj45Lt
make search great again https://t.co/AsLmkqaR68
glad to hear this; excited to bring soon to plus/free tiers! https://t.co/InzDd8knUL
and operator!
unless you live in europe/the uk, but that’s not our fault :(

when we launched the openai pro plan in december i thought it was only a good deal for extreme power users. 

now with the addition of 100 deep research queries per month, unlimited sora, unlimited chatgpt, o1 pro and more stuff to come, i think it is a great deal for many users!
argh, a very small number in our *free* tier, sorry
50 cents of compute for 500 dollars of value
(note: this is not the "one-more-thing" for o3-mini. few more days for that.)

congrats to the team, especially @isafulf and @EdwardSun0909, for building an incredible product.

my very approximate vibe is that it can do a single-digit percentage of all economically valuable tasks in the world, which is a wild milestone.

way back on friday, the high score on "humanity's last exam" was o3-mini-high at 13%.

now on sunday, deep research gets 26.6%.
give it a try on your hardest work task that can be solved just by using the internet and see what happens.

this version will have something like 10/month in our plus tier and a very small number in our plus tier, but we are working on a more efficient version.

(this version is built on o3.)

it is very compute-intensive and slow, but it's the first ai system that can do such a wide variety of complex, valuable tasks.

going live in our pro tier now, with 100 queries per month.

plus, team, and enterprise will come soon, and then free tier.

people will post lots of great examples, but here is a fun one:

i am in japan right now and looking for an old NSX. i spent hours searching unsuccessfully for the perfect one. i was about to give up and deep research just...found it.

today we launch deep research, our next agent.

this is like a superpower; experts on demand!

it can go use the internet, do complex research and reasoning, and give you back a report.

it is really good, and can do tasks that would take hours/days and cost hundreds of dollars.
got one more o3-mini goody coming for you soon--i think we saved the best for last!
soon we will need another exam... https://t.co/XVCdVcGHLL

o3-mini-high is really good and it's cool to hear some people say it's their favorite model ever

but

it reminds me of when we used to have something internally called "the little big run"

a top 2025 goal is to fix our naming problem

check out how more details here, especially worth noting the performance of high.

also, team really delivered on API pricing!

https://t.co/TSPTgnzphF

a lot of people prefer this to o1, and it's just the mini model.

now we work on the big brother.

o3-mini is out!

smart, fast model.

available in ChatGPT and API.

it can search the web, and it shows its thinking.

available to free-tier users! click the "reason" button.

with ChatGPT plus, you can select "o3-mini-high", which thinks harder and gives better answers.
why not 100x? https://t.co/IgKK3i4umO
first full 8-rack GB200 NVL72 now running in azure for openai—thank you @satyanadella and jensen!

visited @Helion_Energy today.

the machine is making rapid progress (and the scale is nuts)--it feels like walking through a sci-fi movie!
next phase of the msft x oai partnership is gonna be much better than anyone is ready for!! https://t.co/LL6rUDDy50
look forward to bringing you all AGI and beyond.

but mostly we are excited to continue to execute on our research roadmap and believe more compute is more important now than ever before to succeed at our mission.

the world is going to want to use a LOT of ai, and really be quite amazed by the next gen models coming.

deepseek's r1 is an impressive model, particularly around what they're able to deliver for the price.

we will obviously deliver much better models and also it's legit invigorating to have a new competitor! we will pull up some releases.
fun watching people react to operator. reminds me of the chatgpt launch!

ok we heard y’all.

*plus tier will get 100 o3-mini queries per DAY (!)
*we will bring operator to plus tier as soon as we can
*our next agent will launch with availability in the plus tier

enjoy 😊 https://t.co/w8sFsq6mI1

A revolution can be neither made nor stopped. The only thing that can be done is for one of several of its children to give it a direction by dint of victories.

-Napoleon
stargate site 1, texas, january 2025.
big. beautiful. buildings. https://t.co/8lAvUufXFm

doing an openai livestream right now, first agent launch!

https://t.co/m89GVmQ6Uo

big news: the free tier of chatgpt is going to get o3-mini!

(and the plus tier will get tons of o3-mini usage)
just one more mean tweet and then maybe you'll love yourself...

watching @potus more carefully recently has really changed my perspective on him (i wish i had done more of my own thinking and definitely fell in the npc trap).

i'm not going to agree with him on everything, but i think he will be incredible for the country in many ways!
build monuments in the desert
🩵 https://t.co/CMRjgUZfRt

twitter hype is out of control again. 

we are not gonna deploy AGI next month, nor have we built it.

we have some very cool stuff for you but pls chill and cut your expectations 100x!

thank you to the external safety researchers who tested o3-mini.

we have now finalized a version and are beginning the release process; planning to ship in ~a couple of weeks.

also, we heard the feedback: will launch api and chatgpt at the same time!

(it's very good.)
whitney is one of the most impressive founders i know and i'm thrilled she is returning to be ceo of bumble! great news for the company.
it was a personal contribution as you state; i am confused about the questions given that my company did not make a decision.
funny, they never sent me one of these for contributing to democrats... https://t.co/xjpanXSb5D
an important thing for us to do now is figure out how to make this new kind of model very easy to use!
(and i super appreciate when people change their minds with more data!)
it's been fun watching the vibes shift on o1 (including pro) as people learn how to use it https://t.co/0CwT1EjPpi
My sister has filed a lawsuit against me. Here is a statement from my mom, brothers, and me: https://t.co/Nve0yokTSX

insane thing: we are currently losing money on openai pro subscriptions!

people use it much more than we expected.
reflections: https://t.co/rHdE40AuOG

(it's supposed to either be about 1. the simulation hypothesis or 2. the impossibility of knowing when the critical moment in the takeoff actually happens, but i like that it works in a lot of other ways too.)

i always wanted to write a six-word story. here it is:
___

near the singularity; unclear which side.

common themes:

AGI
agents
much better 4o upgrade
much better memory
longer context
“grown up mode”
deep research feature
better sora
more personalization

(interestingly, many great updates we have coming were mentioned not at all or very little!) https://t.co/lMZmlZif66
and i'm very in favor of people trying aggressive experiments to improve them
algorithmic feeds are the first at-scale misaligned AIs

it is hard to overstate how much alec radford has contributed to the field, and how much of everyone's current progress traces back to his work.

i believe he is a genius at the level of einstein, and also he is one of my favorite people ever--hard to imagine a nicer, warmer, or… https://t.co/lw02VcUi38
i especially want to thanks @MillionInt who relentlessly leads the strawberry team--getting to this point was one of the best displays of leadership in openai history, with much more to come.

it's also extremely hard to rally a big talented research team to charge a new hill in the fog together.

this is key to driving progress forward.

thanks to ilya, jakub, bob, mark, and many other exceptional research leaders who got us here.

it is (relatively) easy to copy something that you know works.

it is extremely hard to do something new, risky, and difficult when you don't know if it will work.

individual researchers rightly get a lot of glory for that when they do it! it's the coolest thing in the world.
what would you like openai to build/fix in 2025?

i think the wsj is the overall best us newspaper right now, but they published an article called "The Next Great Leap in AI Is Behind Schedule and Crazy Expensive" many hours after we announced o3?! 

https://t.co/JkA83TNTfO
you can just do things
